But GOD do I hate playing it sometimes. I spend like 40% of my time actually playing fun and challenging matches that actually feel like what the game was meant for. And the other 60% getting steamrolled because of the bad matchmaking and the absolute worst of teammates. The AI of the bots is awful (running in front off a guy firing a bazooka seems like a good idea to them) and historical accuracy concerning uniforms and weapons is non-existent. The grinding is honestly doable compared to War Thunder. The community is filled with cheaters, sweats and the most unskilled spray-and-prayers known to man. It's not pay to win but rather pay to collect (which upsets me as someone who likes to collect every squad and see what works best), the events often require money to be fully completed AND still have a life. Also a lot of players hate on snipers and mortarmen who take their job seriously, they think everyone should just charge the objective even when their literal role on the battlefield is to keep their distance.

About the matchmaking: I think the BR-system is just an awful system. It works with War Thunder but is so bad for the realism and gameplay of Enlisted.

But beneath all of this nonsense is still a really fun game that I will just keep playing no matter what. I somehow always circle back to this game and I will always love it and hate it at the same time.

Enlisted is a tactical World War II shooter that delivers intense battles, customizable squads, and a strong sense of realism — all without falling into a pay-to-win model, since progress relies far more on skill and strategy than on purchases. The game is also updated frequently by the developers, who add new content, balance weapons, and improve overall quality, keeping the community active and the gameplay constantly evolving.
Despite its strengths, Enlisted still struggles with a matchmaking system that often creates uneven teams, placing new players against highly upgraded squads or mixing experienced users with under-equipped teammates, which can lead to lopsided battles. This issue is compounded by the weak AI that controls your squad members, who frequently expose themselves unnecessarily, fail to take cover, and react slowly to threats. In some matches, entire teams may be filled with bots, and these AI-controlled players tend to perform poorly, contributing little to objectives and reducing the overall competitiveness and immersion of the match.
Even though these issues exist, I still enjoy Enlisted a great deal — it’s genuinely fun to play, with chaotic battles that keep the adrenaline high. Sometimes I wish the game had a slightly slower pace to better appreciate the tactical side of combat, but in the end, I remind myself that it’s portraying the intensity of war, and that fast, unpredictable action is part of what makes the experience so engaging.

As much as I'd like to recommend this game... here are the reasons why I don't:

1. The most serious reason - the praised "squads" you control are nothing less than cannon fodder and some sort of backup if you fail to break through enemy positions by yourself. Your AI squad members do absolutely nothing... they just stand around gazing at the enemy while some player mows them down with a submachine gun.

Which brings us to the next point ....

2. Submachine guns in this game are shamelessly overpowered. The Russian and American ones, which are far superior to the German and Japanese in terms of rate of fire, almost never miss and sometimes you get shot over a distance where even a bolt-action rifle can have a problem. Combined with the sheer stupidity of the AI teammates, it's often enough for one player to run into a room with a submachine gun soldier and wipe out your entire squad without you even having a chance to react.

3. The tank battles... or something like that. If you think the tank battles in this game are atmospheric - think again. Often your own bullet gets stuck in an invisible wall while the enemy tank uses that to shoot you down. The most distressing part of the story is watching as you are repeatedly thrown back into the "soldier selection view" hit after hit, because one of your tank crews dies every 2 seconds. 
Furthermore, you can usually hardly drive further than the spawn point, because either the first gas-crazed soldiers with their bazookas/anti-tank rifles are already waiting for you, or explosive assassins simply run towards your tank, because we cannot assume that the 12 AI soldiers around your tank have even the slightest incentive to protect your tank. Also every hole in the ground may be the end of your tank adventure.. may it holes in the street or artillery bombing craters... once you fall into one of these you're done. In addition, on some maps, the "allowed" zone for you to navigate in is so small and inhospitable that you should forego to use a vehicle in the first place.

4. The lobbies are usually full and matches load fast, but missing "real" players are simply replaced by bots. The team with more "real" players wins. Period. Because more "real" players mean more markers. More markers would give you, as a tank commander or bomber pilot, the advantage of actually being able to see the enemy, or at least get an idea of where the enemy tanks are going. Therefore - no markers means no tactical awareness - means you have to be on a lookout for so many threats that you easily get overwhelmed by one or two enemy soldiers blasting you off the map with TNT or whatever they carry.

5. The render range for effectively seeing anything as a pilot while flying towards the combat zone is ridiculous. I fly an HS129 with a 75mm cannon... no bombs... so I have to hit the target directly. This is quite difficult in two ways: 

a. Almost nobody marks enemy tanks or guns.
b. Independently identifying targets becomes very difficult with a 1000m view range. It's not fun. 
And even if you manage to get the hang of that.. after killing of 10 tanks in one match didn't make any difference thanks to 90% bots in my team.

6. Pay to Win - You can easily buy equipment, or even entire "squads" that then show up with unnaturally bizarre weapons or vehicles. Why research new equipment when you can simply buy submachine guns and sniper rifles?

7. The entire squad system is utter g**bage. It's great that you can eventually have a radio operator, machine gunner, and maybe even an anti-tank gunner in an infantry unit, but it's completely pointless if they get shot at the first enemy contact without having done their job – there we are again with the incredibly s**pid AI. I've started shrinking my squads to a minimum to reduce the "gifted" kills for the enemy. Unfortunately, that defeats the purpose of the squad system and feels restricting.

8. The game mode "Annihilation" in which one team has to plant explosives and the other has to protect these explosive locations... defusing the bomb, once it's armed, takes so long that it usually doesn't make sense to fight for it at all... So you have to retreat and hope that your teammates manage to hold the position properly this time, while you desperately try to set up sandbags and ammunition crates as the engineer. Building up a MG Squad also just does not work well as no one cares for guarding the flanks. 


I loved the game at first... I played it for 8 hours a day, without a break. I reached Battle Rating 2 and realized that my team's skill level hadn't changed at all. I assumed that at least there, the players would have a bit more sense than what I saw at the beginning. 

Although there are moments when I really enjoy it, I'm finding myself increasingly frustrated playing this game. Not because I think the weapons are unbalanced or the tank battles are buggy, but rather because the advertised team and squad system simply doesn't exist. For example: tanks aren't protected. Enemy tanks aren't marked. Enemy planes fly around the entire battle, destroying one tank after another—nobody seems to care. No interception attempts are made, no anti-aircraft guns are built, and there's simply no reaction to the current situation - ever(!).

When you realize enemy tanks are breaking through the middle, your own tanks are wasted instead of setting up an ambush. Positions aren't adequately protected, and communication in this game only happens in 1 out of 20 cases. In War Thunder, you can maybe help your team coordinate or warn them of dangers with targeted messages—but in Enlisted, it's pointless because 80% of your teammates are AI bots throwing themselves into enemy fire anyway.

No, I can't recommend this game in its current state, even though it has good graphics and a great atmosphere. Unfortunately, the gameplay doesn't offer anything that would keep me playing long-term. As long as there aren't any decent ways to better coordinate the entire team and as long as missing players are replaced by bots, I'm sorry.

I played Enlisted for 28 hours with a friend.
Me and that friend got to know each other from the *good old days* of Heroes & Generals, which was also a F2P WWII FPS+Strategy online multiplayer game.

People like to complain about how grindy Gaijin games are, but I feel like H&G might as well have been grindier than this.
The graphics definitely beat H&G and at first glance it is amazing to see dozens of soldiers rushing in at the start of battle.

But that is only at first glance. The “Squad” system the devs are so proud of is really awful. You spawn in with a group of soldiers and directly control one of them; the others follow you or move towards a position you designate.
However, the maximum range you can move away from your squad before the “orders” are cancelled and they follow you again is somewhere between 30–60 meters. Which is kind of crap.
Though I could see they wouldn’t want someone playing sniper to just send in the cannon fodder [bots] to see where the enemies are shooting from.

Either way, the AI is very dumb. They mostly just stand around and do not fight nor seek cover adequately, so it is just a bunch of easy kills for both sides. Though they do have some unfair mechanics— I tried to bayonet a bot that was facing away from me, and it turned around 180° and knifed me before my bayonet animation could even halfway complete. You can call it a skill issue, but I find it to be bs.
It also sucks that although you can add soldiers for different roles into a squad, as they will be AI‐controlled, chances are they will die on the spot the moment there are enemies nearby. Wasting your precious Engineer, AT‐gunman, radio operator or what have you.

The community also isn’t that great imo. I am in the lower battle ratings (matchmaking tiers), but I see from other people’s reviews that things don’t really change much in the higher tiers. It’s the typical situation of where an objectives‐based FPS has a bunch of players who just treat it as an ego shooter and don’t bother with the objectives.
This is not specific to Enlisted, but it is worth pointing out that this problem also exists in Enlisted.

A lot of the controls are also really awkward and feel clunky. I was happy to finally get some binoculars to more easily spot and mark enemies, especially tanks, but the default keybinding is the numrow 8 key. And the binoculars do not have a scope/use mode with RMB, you need to unequip the binoculars with its or another weapon/tool’s key to move unencumbered, as the binoculars slow you down.
Thankfully, the keybindings can be remapped, but it still baffles me. Likewise, using the MG in a tank uses the Spacebar. It’s mind‐boggling.

A lot of reviewers also complain about cheaters. Honestly, I have seen some unfair play where people were cheesing some stuff like glitching through some weird places making themselves some really nasty camping spots, scoring top of the leaderboard and no one does anything about them— but that isn’t hacking, it’s just abusing known weaknesses in the game.
I have played with some people who just have excellent game sense and can spot you with just two or three pixels on the screen. I was screensharing as I was playing, and a friend who was not yet playing the game pointed out where an enemy was and slowly told me where to aim and when to shoot, and I got a kill. On a player I would not have seen at all. So I figure the game probably has a lot less hackers than people say it does and it is just salty players who suffer from “skill issue”. I got shot through a wall one time and assumed it was someone using a wallhack, but maybe there was that one tiny crack between the planks that they could see me through— I’ll never know.

All in all, it’s nice to have something try and fill the gap left by RETO-MOTO shutting down and pulling the plug on H&G. For casual use and play, it looks really nice compared to some other free alternatives… but the gameplay focused around squads just sucks. Some people make custom matches where squads are disabled, and others simply bear with it and designate a point behind some obstacles in hopes that the bots will stay out of view and will serve as a quick respawn point for when the character you are controlling gets shot down (you switch to control one of the bot‐controlled characters when you do).

If what I and others brought up don’t sound like a dealbreaker to you, go ahead and have fun.
Otherwise, I suggest you play something else. There aren’t that many active WWII shooters, but there’s plenty of tactical shooters to play.
And, your time is precious. Maybe shilling out some money for a game is better than grinding and doing unpaid work in a “free to play” game for hundreds of hours, when a day’s worth of work gets you a full game or two.

TLDR:
This game is bad. Never mind the pay2win. Never mind the tier systems or the grind. This game is badly designed. It is somehow both too complex for a casual FPS audience and lacks enough rewarding depth for enthusiasts looking for something more tactical. Yet it seems to try to please both and fails completely.

LDR: This game has many problems. There are obvious ones, but some less obvious ones that I don't think are often mentioned properly, but I feel are important to mention.
They can roughly be broken down into a list: Monetization, Matchmaking, Game Mechanics, Progression, and Performance

Monetization:
This game DOES have microtransactions, I would argue the pay to win is negligible, but there are many forms of it in this game.
There is a premium currency used to buy various things in the game.
There is a premium subscription that gives several benefits that are exclusive to the subscription. It expires and you lose all access to that content until you renew it. And there is ALOT. There are premium weapons, premium vehicles, premium squads, premium inventory slots... Pretty much every mechanic to this game has a premium variant to it. There's too much to judge the balance of it all to the free content, but you can find info for that if you look. Stats-wise a good chunk IS better, but impact to a match seems insignificant in my opinion.
There is also a battle pass that refreshes roughly every 30 days or so. It has free rewards you unlock by competing challenges and exclusive content only available by purchasing the pass. If you purchase the pass and play enough to progress through the rewards you can get enough premium currency to afford the pass next rotation, so it pays for itself as long as you play regularly, and the rewards are decent enough.

Progression and Matchmaking: 
If you've played a Gaijin Entertainment game before or heard of World of Tanks or World of Warships or War Thunder, you're familiar with the tier progression system they have for unlocking content. All weapons and vehicles you unlock in Enlisted have a tier: 1 through 5. Higher tiers equal better and generally more powerful stuff.
Having ANY tier equipment equipped puts you in that tier. So if you equip a tier 3 weapon, even if it's one weapon for one guy, you will be matched with other tier 3s. This leads to 1 of 2 options, either you equip the higher tier gear and get matched in that tier - playing with other players who are anywhere from also having 1 higher tier weapon equipped, or kitted out with full higher tier weapons on all their guys - or you have to bide your time, unlocking but not using all the new stuff you unlock until you have enough to equip your squads and not feel underpowered. This is not a new concept, but where this becomes more problematic for Enlisted than say, WoTs for example, is that Enlisted has a more complex, in-depth level of equipping your squads than WoTs. WoTs tier system relies around the Tanks themselves. You unlock one option that determines the tier and chose that one option to bring into a match. With Enlisted, you have so much more to manage that affects your matchmaking tier.
And this is only a problem because the different tiers have such different levels of skill. Unless they are paying their way through, even reaching tier 5 means spending hundreds of hours in game. Feels like subpar game balance to have something as little as 1 rifle with slightly better stats be the difference between how sweaty your next match will be.
Even matchmaking on player skill alone seems unbalanced, often my matches will snowball - one team sweeping the other with little resistance - and it's pretty random which side you'll be on, though I find neither to be any fun. The game also reportedly has a significant problem with hackers, though I haven't 100% confirmed to have encountered any myself. But given the way the game works, it seems rather hard to verify a hacker without watching hours of replays. Which is actually a nice feature to have, both for identifying cheaters and learning the game better.

Game Mechanics and Performance:
This game strikes me as a typical example of a neat idea on paper being poorly executed. Full squads of soldiers individually controlled by a single player who can switch control between them and command them sounds intriguing. The appeal of a RTS and a FPS combined together, almost. Yet where Enlisted feels like it falls short is how awkward and clunky commanding a squad in game is. The game is often too fast paced for any meaningfully complex commands, though the game lacks them anyway, and instead gives you very simple commands instead: wait and attack/defend objective. You can command the whole squad, or each individual soldier, but ultimately there is little point in doing anything other than telling your squad to sit behind something solid while you go actually do something. Your squad AI is effectively worthless. Not wanting to have a squad of aimbotting snipers picking off any player who sticks their head out of cover in the wrong place is one thing (though that happens a lot with real players anyway) but your AI squad can't even be trusted to move behind cover when being shot at, or to reliably fire upon a full squad running out in the open. The AI rarely gets kills and almost never manages to kill a player unless they do something extremely foolish. Which meaning ordering your squad is less about gaining a tactical advantage and more about safeguarding your spare bodies to swap between when you die or need different gear to do something. It feels like the AI was balanced for players who've never played an FPS in their life. Balancing for console players doesn't even justify how useless the AI is to do anything on it's own.
Several of the mechanics of the gameplay also feel clunky and awkward. Personally I have had the most trouble with the "mount weapon" mechanic where you brace your weapon against a surface to significantly reduce recoil at the cost of being a big sitting duck with a fixed firing angle. Half the time you can't even do it when it feels like you should, and it almost never seems to line up to allow you to actually shoot in the direction you want. Overall it feels poorly programmed. Melee also feels weirdly inconsistent. Whether it's a bayonet stab or swinging your combat knife, it feels inconsistent how far or where your melee swings to hit an enemy. If you aren't running into your opponent you probably won't hit them.
Collision boxes also seem very inconsistent, sometimes you can make a shot and hit a the tip of a guy's foot peeking out under a truck and other times your bullets are getting blocked trying to shoot over a fence or through an open window.
Draw distance will also screw you over because depending on settings, other players will load in from further away than things like bushes and other foliage. This means players can often see other players who think they're hidden, but are actually visible because the environment they're hiding behind isn't actually there

Enlisted is a foundationally broken game. Why do I play it? Because it is incredibly fun. Both can be true at the same time. For any developers reading this, please, please fix your game. I have over 200+ hours in Enlisted and certain things are not being fixed, and have never been fixed since I first downloaded. Developers PLEASE pay attention to your fan base and look at what I have written below, these are common complaints from all the players I have spoken to. 

.Squads do not keep up with you EVER!!!!! they stay miles behind you, then if they catch up they stand around like morons and get sniped or bombed. They do not obey your command to stay close and this has ruined many, MANY sessions with my friends.

.Many maps are completely bias to the defenders, with terrible starting spawns for the attackers. The outskirts of Moscow map being a great example of this. You start, as the attackers, opposite a no mans land that you have to cross with a fortified area as the defensive point to capture. The amount of losses I have had on this map alone as the attacker is beyond ridiculous. It's not that it isn't possible to win as an attacker, it is that it always feels unbalanced.

.Many buildings have no windows on the sides where enemies attack from. This is unforgivable. The amount of times I have tried to find a window facing attackers in buildings, only to be confronted by a solid wall is infuriating. You designed these maps, yet the windows are always in useless positions. 

.Early tanks have paper thin armour, to the point they are useless to play as. I am a very experienced tanker on the game, and I have successfully utilised the early tanks in the game from all factions, but they are a complete pain to use and a lot of the fun is taken away from using them early on because they are so weak. Additionally the tank rifles are practically useless. 

.The grind on late stage popular weapons is WAYYYYYYYY to grindy. I'm sorry, I know you are a free to play game, but I have been playing 200+ hours and have only just started to enjoy my loadouts. We all know you need to make money, but the amount of research points needed on some of these weapons is unreasonable. 

.Why is the German halftrack (one of the most iconic vehicles of WW2) locked behind a £20 paywall? like wtf, who thought that was a fair price? Even in a free game!!! It is one vehicle and not even a particularly powerful one. 

.Some late game tanks have ridiculous HP. I once went up against a panther tank (No slouch of a tank to be sure) and I shot 7 bazooka shots at it, blew 2 TNT packs on its back, and threw multiple explosive packs at it, only to be wiped out in one shot by it. This isn't realism, this isn't balanced, this isn't fun! 

.It is incredibly easy to get stuck on the environment whether it be in tanks, or while playing as infantry. I have died so many times, beyond count, from being caught on invisible tiny barriers that should not even register (particularly to a tank). The mantling is also really broken, with it getting you stuck in windows, or allowing you to crawl through tiny spaces, giving an unfair advantage. 

.The game has server issues, my friend is constantly booted out of games and I often experience Lag, despite having excellent internet coverage. 

.When in a tank you should be able to shoot down trees and walls in order to get a better view of the map. WAY to many times I have been firing rounds from a giant tank at a tree or wall, for it to stay there like nothing happened, ruining my view and leading to my death when i try to reposition. This is basic. We aren't expecting full destructibility, but the walls and trees need to be able to be shot down. Really simple stuff. 

.Having a squad be mixed nationalities is also really really annoying. If you are like me, you want to RP with the correct gear and troops of the time period. When you put a different squad member in lets say a British squad, you can often get an American in there randomly, breaking immersion. I am aware this can be changed via the appearance screen, but this requires in game currency to unlock, which makes it a really sleazy way to milk more money out of people. Make it free!

.The hit markers on anti infantry shells and bombs are completed broken. I have had a bomb kill my whole squad (Many many times) from literally miles away, where there was absolutely no way I could have been hit, and the same applies to tank shells. Paradoxically the anti-infantry shells are completely unreliable. Sometimes you will shoot one right next to someone, nothing, another time you will get a random kill from ages away, that you weren't even aiming at. It is pretty basic stuff again. 

.The weapon upgrade system is completely stupid, literally no other way I can accurately describe it. Why should I have to play hours and hours with a squad I don't like so I can upgrade a gun I use, that is for some (no) reason tied to that squad? Honestly more scummy milking of your fanbase. 

I will end it here but there are more issues I haven't mentioned. I really want to recommend this game. It has genuinely fun moments and I wouldn't have this much time in it otherwise, but ultimately the game is extremely imperfect at the moment. On a side note, it would be great to see a Russia V Japan map, in Korea, but that is the least of my concerns at the moment.
